flowRoot.flowPara: The hot plasma is kept from touching the walls of the machine by the use of strong magnetic fields 100,000 times stronger than the earth's field at the surface. The magnetic fields are generated by sets of coils surrounding the tokamak. To learn more about these magnets and their interaction with plasma PRESS "M".

Scientists use a variety of methods to heat the plasma. While the main way is through the induced current (see Central Solenoid), auxiliary sources of power are needed to reach the conditions for fusion. Shown is a radiofrequency heating antenna launching electromagnetic waves into the tokamak. To learn more about auxiliary sources PRESS "M".

The central solenoid is an electromagnet that induces a current inside the plasmas. This current is responsible for, both, heating the plasma as well a providing an essential component of the magnetic field required for confinement. In this simluation, the current increases proportional to the magnetic field. PRESS "M" to learn more.

The tokamak itself is a stailess steel toroidal shell that is kept at ultra high vacuum. The fuel (deuterium and tritium) is injected into the vessel and the density of the plasma can be changed (among other methods) by varying the amount of fuel injected into the machine. For more info about the vacuum vessel and density control PRESS "M".

Press this button to enter the tokamak reactor cell. The tokamak is the most studied magnetically confined plasma device in the world. The final objective of the research is to use the tokamak to create electricity via fusion energy. In the Virtual Tokamak simulator, you are the operator of an energy producing tokamak reactor. You must maximize the electric power produced while being careful not to damage the machine by making the plasma unstable. All of the plasma physics in this simulation is real albeit simplified.
To learn more about plasma, fusion and tokamaks, PRESS "M".
To remotely turn on and study a real plasma, visit the Remote Glow Discharge Experiment by PRESSING "R".

Press this button to enter the heat and tritium exchanger system. Once the conditions for sustained fusion within the tokamak are obtained, the reactions generate energetic helum nuclei and neutrons (at energies millions of times higher than those of fossil fuel reactions). This energy ultimately heats the blanket and wall of the tokamak. The heat and tritium exchanger convert this heat to usable electricity. Another job of the cycle is to extract the tritium atoms produced in the blanket and inject them back into the tokamak to be used as fuel.
To learn more about the exchangers PRESS "M".

Press this button to view the city being powered by fusion. This is the final step in fusion energy production: Getting the electricity produced via fusion to the people that need it, be it to power cities, industries, electric vehicles, etc.

The Virtual Tokamak can produce more than 1GW of electricity, enough to power a city the size of Seattle, WA (check this), while consuming only about 500 pounds of fuel a year (50% deuterium, 50% tririum). How much electricity can you make it produce?
To learn more about the potential energy production of fusion and its efficiency PRESS "M"

The vacuum vessel is surrounded by a thick shell mostly made out of lithium. The fusion reactions in the reactor create energetic neutrons that are ejected towards the blanket heating it through collisions. The lithium in the blanket also reacts with the neutrons producing tritium. The heat and tritium are extracted from the Blanket via cooling channels. To learn more PRESS "M"

The blanket is cooled by liquid lithium lead (LiPb) which, once it's flown through the blanket, is heated and carries the bred tritium. The first step upon leaving the blanket is to pass through a tritium extraction system which diffuses the tritium away from the LiPb and channels it back towards the tokamak as fuel. To learn more PRESS "M"

Once the heat has been transfered to the helium in the heat exchanger, the hot helium is processed through a cycle which converts heat to rotational kinetic energy of turbines. These, in turn serve as power generators, producing electricity. For more details, including the use of He vs water PRESS "M".

Once the tritium is extracted from the hot liquid lithium lead (LiPb), the latter is fed to a heat exchanger which is coupled to a helium loop. The heat is transfered from the LiPb to the helium. The cooled LiPb returns to the blanket while the heated helium heads to the electricity producing turbines. To learn more PRESS "M".
